raw_text:
UK needs tax cuts, Tories insist
 
 A major change of direction is needed in Britain if it is to prosper, the shadow chancellor said as the Tory Party spring conference began.
 
 Oliver Letwin said the UK could not compete with other countries without the £4bn tax cuts he was promising. Tory co-chairman Liam Fox had opened the forum in Brighton with an attack on Labour's record and party leader Michael Howard is due to speak later. Tony Blair has said Conservative policies would cause economic failure. But Mr Letwin said Britain had fallen from fourth to 11th in the international economic competitiveness league.
 
 "Can this country compete, can this country prosper, unless we do something about the burden of regulation and tax on our economy?" he said. "If we are going to take on the great challenges, the challenges like those posed by the Chinese and the Indians, we have got to do something about getting down the burden of regulation and getting down the burden of tax," he said. "The fact is the very carefully costed, fully funded plans we have laid out for saving £12bn by 2007-2008 are absolutely crucial to delivering an economy that will prosper and provide people with jobs and indeed provide the public services with the money they need on a sustainable long-term basis." Mr Letwin said voting for Labour meant choosing higher taxes, borrowing and waste.
 
 Earlier, Dr Fox had said Labour's rule had been characterised by "lost trust and failure to deliver". He also attacked the government's "failure" to control immigration and asylum and criticised its record on the NHS, telling delegates Labour cannot be trusted on education or crime. A Tory government would sort out the "shambles" of immigration, put patients before statistics and bring discipline to schools, he said. Michael Howard, who had been due to welcome delegates to the conference on Friday, will address them in a lunchtime speech. His welcome address had to be postponed after he stayed in London to lead the party's opposition to the Prevention of Terrorism Bill in its lengthy progress through Parliament. The bill was finally passed on Friday evening, after more than 30 hours of debate. Mr Howard is likely to defend his party's handling of the bill, which was only passed after the Conservatives accepted Prime Minister Tony Blair's promise that MPs would be able to review it within a year.
llama3.2:1b: The shadow chancellor, Oliver Letwin, said the UK needs £4bn tax cuts to compete with other countries and prosper.
He criticized Labour for not delivering on economic issues.
Letwin stated that if Conservatives take on major challenges like China and India, they must address burden of regulation and tax.
The party will focus on saving £12bn by 2007-2008 through cost-cutting measures, which are crucial to a sustainable economy.
llama3.2:3b: The UK needs tax cuts to prosper, according to shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin, citing competition with other countries as a factor.
Tory co-chairman Liam Fox attacked Labour's record and argued a Conservative government could sort out immigration and improve education.
Michael Howard will speak later about the party's handling of the Prevention of Terrorism Bill.
gemma2:2b: The shadow chancellor, Oliver Letwin, argued for tax cuts and deregulation as essential for Britain's economic competitiveness.
He highlighted the UK's decline in international rankings and emphasized the need for these changes to enable prosperity and service provision.
Liam Fox criticized Labour's record on immigration, the NHS, education, and crime, claiming they lack trustworthiness.
The conference commenced with his remarks, followed by Michael Howard's speech postponed due to the debate on the Prevention of Terrorism Bill.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Michael Howard is due to speak later.
Labour has been attacked for losing trust and failing to deliver.
Government plans for £12bn by 2007-2008 are crucial to delivering an economy that will prosper and provide jobs.
Dr Fox said the government's rule had been characterised by lost trust, failure to deliver and a failed immigration policy.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin calls for £4bn tax cuts and deregulation reforms to boost UK competitiveness internationally and address rising economic challenges compared to other nations.
qwen2.5:3b: A major change in direction is needed for Britain to prosper, according to shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin.
He claims £4bn tax cuts are essential to compete with other countries, which Britain has fallen from fourth to 11th place internationally.
Letwin argues that reducing regulation and taxes will help tackle challenges posed by China and India.
The Tory party conference in Brighton features Letwin's speech criticizing Labour for higher taxes, borrowing, and inefficiency.
Co-chairman Liam Fox highlights Labour’s "lost trust" and failure to deliver while criticizes the government on immigration control, NHS performance, and education crime issues.
Michael Howard will address delegates later defending his party's handling of the Prevention of Terrorism Bill, which faced significant legislative opposition before being passed.
opencoder:1.5b: A major change of direction is needed in Britain if it is to prosper, the shadow chancellor said as the Tory Party spring conference began.
The UK needs tax cuts, Oliver Letwin said.
Britain had fallen from fourth to 11th in the international economic competitiveness league.
Tony Blair has said Conservative policies would cause economic failure.
Mr Letwin said Britain had lost from a great challenge like those posed by the Chinese and the Indians.

However, he also mentioned that it's crucial to deliver an economy that will prosper and provide people with jobs and indeed provide the public services with the money they need on a sustainable long-term basis.
smollm:1.7b:
The UK needs tax cuts and Tories insist on them for several reasons:

1.
To prosper: The UK can't compete with other countries without these tax cuts, as they are not competitive in terms of taxation.
This is why the UK has fallen from 4th to 11th place in international economic competitiveness.

To save £12bn by 2007-2008: The UK needs to reduce its tax burden and implement policies that will help it achieve this goal, which requires significant investments in infrastructure, education, and healthcare.
To control immigration: The UK has a large number of immigrants, which is a major concern for the government.
By controlling immigration, the government can ensure that there are enough jobs available to absorb the new arrivals.
To improve the NHS: The UK's National Health Service (NHS) is one of its most important public services.
By improving the NHS, the government can reduce healthcare costs and provide better care to its citizens.
To bring discipline to schools: The UK has a well-established education system, but there are concerns about the quality of education in some areas.
By implementing policies that promote discipline and accountability in schools, the government can improve the overall quality of education in the country.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The UK needs tax cuts to prosper if they don't revert to regressive policies.
Oliver Letwin suggests a £4bn tax cut would help compete with other countries.
The Conservative Party's shadow chancellor called for a change of direction.
Tory co-chairman Liam Fox attacked Labour's record, while Tony Blair criticized Conservative policies for economic failure.
Mr. Letwin emphasized the importance of addressing regulation and taxes to build a thriving economy.
Labour's past issues with trust and immigration control were criticized by Dr. Fox.
The conference will focus on immigration reform, statistics, and school discipline, aimed at reversing corruption and rebuilding public services sustainably.
tinyllama:1.1b: The UK needs tax cuts, as Torie Party co-chairman Liam Fox has promised in his opening speech at the spring conference of the Tories.
In his address, Fox attacked Labour's record and party leader Michael Howard is scheduled to speak later on Friday.

Tony Blair has stated that Conservative policies would cause economic failure, but Fox said that Britain has fallen from fourth place to 11th in international economic competitiveness league due to regulatory and tax burdens.
Fox plans to deliver a costed plan for saving £12 billion by 2007-2008, which will be crucial to delivering jobs and public services on a sustainable long-term basis.
The Conservative Party leader is expected to defend his party's handling of the Prevention of Terrorism Bill during his luncheon speech at the conference.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The UK government announced plans to cut taxes during the spring conference held by the Tory Party in Brighton.
This move is expected to help boost the economy and attract more investments to boost job creation.
However, critics argue that such tax cuts could undermine the competitiveness of Britain against other countries and harm the welfare state.
phi:2.7b: The UK needs tax cuts in order to compete with other countries and prosper.
Shadow Chancellor Oliver Letwin says Britain has fallen from fourth to 11th in the international economic competitiveness league due to high taxes and regulation.
He promises to reduce the burden of regulation and tax by £12bn by 2007-2008, which will provide jobs and public services on a sustainable long-term basis.
Labour's record is characterized by lost trust and failure to deliver, while Tories would control immigration, prioritize patients over statistics in healthcare and bring discipline to schools.
Michael Howard's speech was postponed due to the government' s Preventative Terrorism Bill being passed after much debate.
orca-mini:3b: UK Conservatives want tax cuts worth £12 billion by 2007-2008 to improve economic competitiveness.
Shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin said competitive economies require lower taxes and less regulation.
Liam Fox, Tory co-chairman, attacked Labour's record on immigration and education, while Michael Howard vowed to tackle the "shambles" of the NHS.
The Prevention of Terrorism Bill was passed after more than 30 hours of debate, with Tory opposition leading to a revised bill.
hermes3:3b: UK needs tax cuts, Tories insist on.
Oliver Letwin argues UK needs £4bn cuts for economic competition.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The UK's shadow chancellor, Oliver Letwin, insisted that £4bn tax cuts were necessary for Britain to compete and prosper.
He cited a decrease in international economic competitiveness as evidence of the need for change.
Letwin argued that lowering regulation and taxes would lead to an economy providing jobs and sustainable public services.
Tory Party co-chairman Liam Fox criticized Labour's record, particularly on immigration and healthcare, while Tony Blair claimed Conservative policies could result in economic failure.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The UK needs tax cuts to remain competitive, insisted Shadow Chancellor Oliver Letwin at the Tory Party spring conference.
He argued that Britain had dropped in global economic rankings and could not compete without reducing taxes and regulations.
Letwin defended the Conservatives' £4bn tax cut plan, claiming it was essential for economic growth and public services.
Tory co-chairman Liam Fox criticized Labour's governance, citing failures in trust, immigration control, the NHS, education, and crime.
Party leader Michael Howard, delayed by parliamentary debates on the Prevention of Terrorism Bill, is expected to defend the Conservatives' stance on the bill in his speech.
Tony Blair warned that Tory policies would lead to economic failure.
stablelm2:1.6b: UK needs tax cuts for prosperity, says shadow chancellor Oliver Letwin as Tory Party conference begins; falling from fourth to 14th place in international economic competitiveness league due to high taxes and regulation.
Voting for Labour means choosing higher taxes, borrowing, and waste.

Tory co-chairman Liam Fox criticized Labour's record, but Letwin emphasized the importance of funding plans saving £10bn by 2027-28 for a prosperous economy that provides jobs and public services with money on a sustainable long-term basis.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The Conservative Party, at its spring conference in Brighton, emphasizes the need for substantial tax cuts to improve Britain's economic competitiveness.

Shadow Chancellor Oliver Letwin argues that current rankings of 11th out of 20 countries in international economic competitability are unacceptable and require significant reductions in regulatory burdens and taxation, estimated at £4bn over four years.
He contends that these measures are essential for addressing global challenges from China and India, ensuring sustainable public services, and fostering job creation.
Tory Co-chairman Liam Fox, in his opening remarks, criticized Labour's record, highlighting lost trust, failures to manage immigration, asylum, the NHS, education, and crime.
Letwin further asserted that voting for Labour means higher taxes, increased borrowing, and waste.

Labor leader Michael Howard is scheduled to speak later, addressing his party's stance on the Prevention of Terrorism Bill, which was passed after Prime Minister Tony Blair promised parliamentary oversight within a year.
